review_body: There is the large place hotel’room in akasaka if want to stay at the family room. We are very happy cause staff are very helpful. Spa here (separated man and women) is free of charge if stay here. Yukata always set in our room everyday with different pattern(adults and younger). The place is instagramable (at night). Hotel location is near restaurant, food local , easy to find, public transportation(train).

We booked to stay in the Centurion Grand but got bumped across the road to the Centurion Vintage. Seems like a common policy.The first room we got didn't even have space for our 3 suitcases so we asked to change. We got the room next door which had just enough floor space for our cases but you needed to step over them to get to the bathroom.Our double bed was wedged into a 3 sided square part of the room so my wife had to climb over me to get out of bed.Our daughter's sofa bed kept splitting into two halves.The bathroom was stolen as a unit from a caravan I think ;-)(we totally understand that in Tokyo rooms size can be an issue but this was farcical)Breakfast was a disaster. On our first morning at approximately 8am we had a 30 minute wait. 2nd morning we came down at 7am and all was good. We came down late on the third morning and the queue was looking like at least 45 minutes so we went back up and came down an hour later and still had to wait 10 minutes.On the plus side the staff were friendly and helpful and always smiling even when surrounded by grumpy customers.Good location close to three Metro stations.

The experience at this hotel was quite unpleasant. When we checked into the hotel, we were told we had a room across the street at a neighboring building call the Vintage. Went to the room, only to find this non smoking room smelled terribly like smoke. Came back down to the front desk to advise and they told us to hang out in the lobby while they cleaned it. Air freshener was sprayed to mask the smell. While waiting in the lobby, their public area /restroom lacked attention (vomit on the floors and toilets).I asked to switch rooms, was given the option to switch rooms for one night and then switch back to a room with a masked smoke smell. Finally, I asked if I booked a 2nd room if we could switch to a room with a king bed and this was agreed upon.Upon returning every time, the floor smelled like there was a sewage leak, walls and doors are super thin, so you can hear anything and everything. Didn’t make it any better that our room was right next to the employee/housekeeping door.Before traveling I was quite excited reading some of the positive reviews. After getting to the hotel I was frustrated and disappointed about the accommodations.I expected slightly more considering I was paying an average of around $230 per night. Had a 2nd reservation for the final days of our vacation and decided that we should move elsewhere.Extra point for location and there was one gentleman at the front desk who tried his best to help.

My two teenaged children and I stayed here. First of all, when you book a room that says “annex”, it means it’s in a separate, older building across the street. Because there were three of us, our room had a sofa bed for the third person. It was not at all comfortable, and took up nearly all of the available space in the room. There is about a foot of space between the beds and the wall. There’s nowhere to even put your suitcase, except in the pathway between the beds. There was also some peeling plaster near one of the beds, and the shower curtain smelled a bit moldy.I should also point out that if you see the room listed for less than you paid for it (as I did), you cannot get a refund unless you contact them the day before you check in.The pros are that it’s close to a train station and there are shops and restaurants nearby, but there are nicer hotels in the same area. I would not stay here again, and I feel cheated because I overpaid for the room.

I understand that tokyo hotels are small but I was really surprised by the size of this. I could not sit on the seat as it was the only place other than my bed to put my bag. The bathroom was just over half the size of the room if that gives you some context. I booked the large room type with a queen bed, I would hate to seethe small one. I was luck to be traveling along, two people would be beside themselves in this room.

The hotel is clean, nicely decorated and staff is polite. But the bedroom is too small and breakfast too simple for the type of hotel. The highest point, in my opinion, is the location. Very close to the subway and many restaurants.
Convenient location,Breakfast included,Own spa,Room reasonably large,Safety box upon request,Lots of restaurant close by,5 minutes walk to subway,12 minutes walk to airport limousine pick up station.

Akasaka is a very good base for Tokyo so location was perfect. The hotel is nice with all amenities plus a good free onsen. However, the room was really tiny - no way we got the 14m2 in the description. Also, WiFi in room didn’t work well.

The hotel was very easy to fine - we got of the subway at Akasaka-Mmitsuke station and it was only a couple of minutes walk. Its surrounded by shops, bars and restaurants so great location. The reception staff were friendly and helpful. The room was an average size Japanese room (small by European standards) but perfectly adequate for us. We were on the 10th floor so had an excellent view across the city. The shower was amazing. The breakfast included a good variety of food - Japanese and western. When we were planning our departure the staff gave us printed info about how to get to the airport and printed out our boarding cards for us - very helpful :)

Stayed at this hotel twice between England rugby game in Sapporo. The location is the standout point of this hotel as it’s within 100-200 metres of pubs, restaurants, cafes and the monorail system. Very comfortable room although I would personally suggest no more than 2 people in a room because it was quite cramped for space. That is honestly the only negative I could come up with for this hotel. Staff were very friendly and very quick to respond to any requests we had.

review_body: They advertise this hotel and you book it BUT you get put across road in another building which isn't that nice. The laundry is a joke and dryers don't dry your clothes properly costing you a lot of money.The breakfast is also quite poor and limited, you'd expect better and had better in cheaper hotels.

Helpful and friendly staff , good breakfast , perfect location , nice decoration of the hotel are the reasons to re-visit the hotel Only downsides are the air condition in the room which worked strangely and the size of the room . We had booked for a room for three ; room was already packed - crowded and once our stuff added , only way of moving was to jump over the things I suggest to ask full detail for the booked room type in advance

This hotel is really nice and well located with many amenities and close to all transportation. There is many places to eat, drink and shopping near to this hotel. many metro and trains that you could take to go your wanted destinations. I like the hotel and the rooms are small but have everything that your need.

We stayed 5 days in a familyroom with four beds on the 14th floor. Large room with beds facing a large window so you can see the skyline in bed. Good cleaning. Big breakfast with mixed japanaise and european style. Even scrambled eggs and bacon. It is in a neighborhood with many restaurants and close to the Metro station. We come back again and have No problem to recomend this place.

Great location, clean, well maintained rooms and facilities. The desk staff was helpful, but had limited English language skills. We thought the breakfast was included , but it was 1400 Yen, don't recommend the breakfast , but the hotel was great for the money Would stay again.

Overall decent stay here (friendly staff, clean, etc.) However the rooms were VERY small. There was three of us in a room so definitely pretty squishy at times. We also booked to stay at the Centurion Grand and when we got there they had put us across the street in the Centurion Vintage? Can’t complain other than the small rooms!
user_name:
Katie O
San Clemente, California, United States

review_body: Excelente hotel!! Great locativo, combinis, good restaurantes, subway, everthing around!! Staff really nice, trying to help you with everthing! The hotel has everthing you need, tooth brush, hair brush, sleepers, shampoo, etc...Roons, a bit small, but it was nothing comparing with the good points!!Loved the experience!! Totaly recomend!!!

On arrival, we were told at around 11am that we couldn’t check in until 15:00. We had been on a 12 hour flight so wouldn’t have minded this as much if they would have had shower facilities or a private space we could have at least had a change of clothes. I understood this though as a lot of hotels don’t allow check in until 14:00/15:00. Around 13:30 we arrived back after a walk around the local area as it was quite a warm day and we weren’t dressed accordingly plus a wave of jet lag. We sat outside the hotel and then saw one of the staff wheel over our luggage to the other hotel (hotel vintage) which puzzled me as we had paid a lot of money and expected to be in the main building. I asked at the reception if we could check in earlier as our room was obviously ready and we were tired. She said we could but proceeded then to tell me it was 10% of the room cost to check in an hour earlier. I agreed to pay this even though due to the language barrier it cost me an additional £150 roughly which is a ridiculous policy when they could see we were jet lagged and had arrived so early just to wait for the room that was ALREADY ready. They then told me about the facilities and that because I have tattoos I can’t use them.. I had read this about Japan on the internet but assumed that it would be public baths in the local area that would have this policy. They should really tell you about this as we were really looking forward to using the spa facilities as it was our honeymoon and wanted a relaxing break. So I had to pay 10% to check in 1 hour early plus couldn’t use half the facilities. I felt I couldn’t even argue due to the language barrier but I would have definitely insisted on money back if it would have been elsewhere as I felt this policy was pretty disgusting. The positive stuff was the breakfast was decent and the room, despite not being at all like the photos, wasn’t too bad. The walls had wear and tear also which isn’t great for the price we paid. Overall our experience in Tokyo was lovely and I felt the hotel was probably one of the better ones in the local area it was just a shame about the policies. Rooms were cleaned everyday at various different times which was really good, WiFi box at an additional fee which was also very helpful. 3/5 stars I feel is appropriate.

The locations is fantastic, in the heart of Akasaka. The rooms are small but this is very common in Japan. However, the room was clean, neat and felt very comfortable. Bathroom was quite ok.The hotel has an onsen and it is great to go there after a non-stop walking day :) The female onsen is across the street

Excellent location. Vibrant neighborhood with many options for good food (especially the ramen shop across the street on the corner). The Big Red Bar next door is probably the best in Akasaka if not in Tokyo. Room was quite sizable and the bathroom as well. Both were immaculately clean. The helpfulness, professionalism, and courtesy of the reception staff including the bell captain is beyond comparison. No need to search for another place to stay next time in Tokyo. Perfect hotel. Domo arigato gozai mas!!!

review_body: It’s my first time to visit Japan and I’m glad my sister booked it here. The room is quite small, but we made it work. The Wi-Fi inside the room is barely functional so I have to go to the lobby to get a better signal. The complimentary breakfast was good. There were a few choices like scrambled eggs, fried eggs, noodles, potatoes, sausages and ham. Coffee was surprisingly good. Our stay also included a fee use of spa on the second floor. That was a nice experience. But it is notable to say that it is a small spa. I only used the bath and not the sauna. Also, just a reminder, “no tattoos allowed the facility”.I will stay here again if given the chance in the future. I love that there are so many restaurant choices outside and that it’s near the Tokyo metro.

We stayed here a few weeks ago for five nights before moving on to Hiroshima, Okinawa and finally Taipei. We were a family of four: two adults and two children. Positives: excellent location. This was our third time in Tokyo and we found Akasaka very conveniently placed. The staff were also friendly and the room fairly clean. Sent an iron and ironing board up to our room promptly when requested, have us umbrellas one day when it was raining and and booked us a taxi to Tokyo Station when we checked out. Negatives: the main issue was the room size. We have stayed in Japan 3 times now and visited other eastern cities such as Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Hong Kong etc. but this room was ridiculously sized. We apparently had a free upgrade too so I dress to think what the standard room was like. I appreciate we didn’t spent a lot of time in the room - we were out exploring the amazing city but still the room was frustratingly cramped. You couldn’t swing a cat around in it so it was a challenge at night before bed and all four of us getting ready in a morning. In terms of luggage, for instance, we ended up leaving everything in our suitcases and just putting our suitcases on the window ledge there was that little space. It didn’t spoil the trip or whatever but for a family of four it was rather disappointing. We would recommend this hotel for couples but maybe not for families.

We were able to snag this hotel with about 3 weeks notice and it worked out great. I actually preferred staying here in Akasaka over our previous stay west of Shinjuku station. This hotel is only 5 minutes or less from the Akasaka-Mitsuke station, which offers convenient access/transfers to the whole region. On your walk to the station, you'll pass by numerous bars and restaurants, a dog/cat cafe, some massage places, and more. And yet, we found our hotel to be extremely quiet; I think we only heard someone talking through the walls once, and we were never bothered by street noise. I was really impressed by the lack of noise and the abundance of things to eat in the area.Our double room was small but seemed average for the places we have stayed in Japan. It was tough to open our large suitcase on the floor, and to open our second bag, we had to use the bed. Whatever. I won't hold this against them because it seems typical. The bed was comfortable enough. Water pressure and temperature in the shower were great. The room had free packets of tea and coffee, too.We opted one morning to have breakfast at their buffet, which is just steps away across the street. It cost about 1900 yen, I believe. This was a touch more than I would prefer to spend for this type of meal, but given the convenience and variety, it was reasonable for one morning. You can also opt to purchase the breakast with your daily room rate, but I preferred to get out into the city rather than eating there every morning. They had a nice arrangement of scrambled eggs, bacon, potatoes, cereal, noodles, toast, bagels, fried rice, miso soup, and more.We did not opt to use their spa/onsen facilities or laundry facilities, but those are available.Special props to the front desk staff, who were extremely polite and helpful. We wanted help calling a local restaurant for a reservation, and a gentleman at the desk helped us without hesitation. They also lent us an umbrella on a rainy day.We were very satisfied with our stay and would be happy to stay here again!

We had a family room since we have five people, including three teenagers. The room was small, even by Japanese standards. It's very well-located for Akasaka, and just two blocks to the subway. Tons of restaurants and bars all around. Lively neighborhood. I was up at 4am for a conference call and stood out on the front patio for it. The amount of activity in the neighborhood at 4am was really impressive. The rooms have a laundry machine, which was helpful. The staff was very friendly, although the English was pretty limited with the few folks we talked with. I see here the breakfast buffet gets pretty mixed reviews. Overall, it was a really good mix of Japanese and Western options; the breakfast staff was super friendly; and all our kids were happy. The breakfast was kind of a no-brainer for us here each day. If we were staying in Akasaka again, we'd probably consider this hotel again. But, for a future trip, we're probably more likely to stay in Shibuya or Harajuku.

Nothing negative to say about this hotel. Two things stood out... 1- The staff is very friendly and helpful. Those we spoke to knew some english, which was helpful since I wasn't wise enough to learn a second language when I was a kid...! Bottom line... very friendly and helpful. 2- Location, location, location. There are a handful of great little places to eat (ramen, sushi, etc) within a two-minute walk, and they have a good little in-house restaurant, too. There is also a 7-11 one minute away. Very convenient to get water bottles, beer/wine, snacks. Also know that you can get Disneyland and/or Sea tickets at 7-11. The best part is the subway. The Ginza Line and Maranouchi Line are both at the station roughly a three-minute walk away.

I was very happy with this hotel. The location is absolutely fantastic and the hotel staff could not have been nicer. Nice clean room (although small). The room was always clean and the bed was very comfortable. I paid in advance for breakfast each day (across the street at their sister hotel) and it was quite good. Would definitely stay at this hotel again

It would be just fine, the room was bit old and some pieces of furniture should be exchanged as they missing parts of paint. Mainly however this hotel I treat as a no go destination due to the charge they were trying to pull on us for the missing key card. It was an ordinary key card nothing unusual and while we couldn’t find it they wanted to charge us 30usd for it! Fortunately we simply left it in the room. Well I don’t think the whole event was worth to spoil the fair feeling of the whole stay.

Stayed here for a few nights while we were in Tokyo.The room was small but still pretty good, everything was nice and clean (However, we made the mistake of booking a smoking room because it was the only twin room left and the cigarette smell was very very strong in the room still when we checked in. Don't make the mistake of booking a smoking room unless you intend to smoke). The bathroom was amazing, very modern and clean, had plenty of linen and toiletries provided for you. The beds are a little bit on the hard side but they were still alright to sleep on. Would recommend if your staying for a brief visit.

The rooms are on the small side, but functional. I had 2 kids with me, so two adults would have the additional room that the extra bed took up. Onsen is 'Men Only'. Great part of Tokyo especially at night, and especially if you are looking for seafood.

We booked a Superior Double room for 3 nights since it has a king size bed (room 1106). It did not disappoint. The bed was a true king size and quite comfortable (mattress wasn't the typical hard feel like many in Japan). Only issue was it took up most the room space. For two people, there wasn't a lot of space to move around however you're not in Japan to stay in the room, right? It didn't bother us. All amenities available in the room - face wash, moisturiser, shampoo etc. Check-in and check-out was a breeze. English speaking staff were available. The hotel is very central to the Tokyo Metro Subway and if you wanted to stay local, the streets around the hotel are buzzing with activity. Plenty of bars and restaurants to choose from. I would definitely recommend this hotel.

I echo what others have said, great location and perfect for families. Just spent 5 nights there as a family of 6. Not easy to find hotels that can accommodate that number but the New Centurion Hotel Classic Akasaka was perfect and made for a fun time.

We stayed there for our holidays in Tokyo. We love the place because it is only less than 5 minutes from the Akasaka-Mitsuke train station. The surrounding area is also nice. There are many eatery and 24 hours minimarkets. I think I saw more than 5 within 5 minutes walk from the hotel. We took the Premium double room with extrabed for our 8 years old daughter. The room was quite small in my opinion. With all the furniture there are probably less than 2 meter square empty spaces. They have laundry facilities and vending machine inside the hotel. One thing to note though, there are two buildings of the hotel. The main one with the lobby and reception and the annex which has the restaurant for breakfast and guest rooms. We got ourselves a room in the annex which I found it a bit inconvinience as we need to dress up just to go to the main building and do our laundry.

Stayed for a week with 3 pax sharing in a room. There was a queen size bed and a pulled out sofa bed for 3 adults at 5ft9 at least. If you are 6ft4 and above, I think in general you will find difficulty to move around in Japan given the lower ceiling and also in the trains. As of all japanese hotel, the room size is good to just sleep in and not for moving around too much. The toilet has all the amenities and more..brush, face toner, face wash, a great Panasonic ionic hairdryer and the usual shampoo etc. I greatly recommend using the small bathtub for a soak at the end of the day. You can get bath salt from the pharmacy at the corner and it is super relaxing after all the walking in Tokyo. They have a hot bath in the hotel which my husband went to and says it was good. The room also comes equipped with a humidifier and air filter. Ours was a smoke free room and my super sensitive nose was fine. The location is just less than 5 minutes walk from Akasaka excel hotel where the airport limousine stops. You will be spoilt for choices for the rows of restaurants lined up. The subway is just 3-4mins walk for heading down direct to Omotesando and Shibuya. You can take the Ginza or Marunouchi line. As the hotel is on a street of restaurants, on Friday nights, you might hear some nosies from some people who are a little high. But the Japanese tend to be very well behaved. We were lucky we didn’t get any disturbance during our stay.

We were pleasantly surprised by this hotel. The room was a decent size (we had a twin with 2 adults & 2 kids). The room was clean and had a couple of nice extras - my absolute favourite was a smart phone in the room that you could take out with you (free) - the GPS alone was a life saver (and no roaming charges!) The hotel is only a couple of minutes from the metro (although we got a taxi from Tokyo Station because after a long flight with bags & tired kids we couldn’t face it! It was about 2,000 yen). There are heaps of restaurants, convenience stores and a Don Quijote nearby. Only two issues we had - they really need blackout curtains because the ones in our room didn’t keep much light out so our kids woke earlier than they otherwise would, and the room was quite warm (and the air con temp couldn’t be changed). Laundry onsite, with vending machines and a microwave. The breakfast was ok. Overall, pretty happy with the value and level of amenity.

We stayed for multiple nights. The room was comfortable, clean with a Japanese module bathroom. Enough room for 3 people to be comfortable. The location was the best thing about this hotel. Set in the old part of Tokyo (cobbled roads), we had quick access to the Akasaka Mitsuke train Station which allowed us to travel everywhere in Tokyo. Varied and reasonably priced shops all around the hotel location - useful when buying small goods, items of convenience etc.

The hotel is about 5 mins walk from the Akasaka Mitsume metro station. First impression of the hotel upon entering the lobby is the amount of left luggages , almost packing the entire lobby space. Must be a really popular hotel. I discovered later that Centurion has a few hotels within the vicinity. As the hotel is enjoying a high occupancy rate , we were able to check in after 3pm only. So we left our luggages with the hotel and went around Shibuya/Harajuku area. Around the hotel were streets filled with restaurants , convenience shops , bars , etc. We eventually check in after 5pm and our luggages were already brought up to the room. We were given Room 1403 which is a family room good for 4. The room size is quite small but consists of 2 queen size beds and a bunk bed which easily fit a family of 4 although the remaining walking space is limited. If you have 2 big luggages , that will take up almost the entire room. The toilet is good size and the bath is separate from the toilet area. Overall , I would say that the room is comfortable for family and consists of all amenities one would expect from a tourist class hotel. What impresses me most is the onsen spa on the 2nd floor which opens 24hours. Male guests can access it for free but female patrons will have to go to another spa located about 2 mins walk in another hotel. The onsen spa is pretty huge by Japanese standard and even come with a resting area with private TV/massage chair. After a tiring day out in Tokyo , one can relax in the onsen spa and ease away the strain and pain for the day. A good hotel for family at a great location with a very reasonable price. Highly recommended !!!

The smell when entering the foyer was very musty and mouldy and when we entered our room on the third floor, we were surprised by how small it was, even for Tokyo. There was a double bed in the corner of the room which meant I had to crawl over my husband to leave the bed. If the suitcase was open on the floor, the other person was trapped on whichever side they were standing. The bathroom was like something in a motor home and only fits one person at a time and you have to warn the other person that you’re going to open the door in case they’re standing on the other side. The apparent Onsen is not an Onsen. It is baths with regular tap water that you share with others. There is a bath for men in the building but ladies have to go around the block to another location. Also, travel to and from this station isn’t covered by the Japan Rail pass. Having said this, the front desk staff were very helpful when we wished to transfer our luggage to another hotel using the Yamato service.

In a great location near many restaurants, bars and cafes and a short walk to the underground railway station, giving us good access to the rest of Tokyo. However, the restaurants in Akasaka were a bit pricey and many had a cover charge, so check before you sit down. The room was small, comfortable and clean. Staff were friendly and efficient with a good level of English. The buffet breakfast was at a Centurion hotel across the road and was a selection of Japanese and western food. We would be happy to stay there again.

We chose this hotel for its central location in Tokyo and easy access to the underground. This proved to be a good choice as it was a lively (but not noisy) area with a wide range of restaurants. The hotel was small and the rooms were a bit cramped, but it was a pleasant hotel which was okay for a week and overall, was good for the price. The breakfast was good, but served across the street. The female onsen was also in another hotel. The bathroom was small with only a bath tub/shower. The WiFi worked great.

Don't ever stay at this hotel. Poor service and the room very very small. I booked for 3person. They gaves me diffrent room from the foto that they shows us at the profile. We can't even open our luggage. Don't trust with picture they shows you. Tricky!!

The lo ‘tis great, walking distance from the Akasaka-Mitsuko subway station; many small restaurants around with good food.The rooms and bathrooms are very small.The staff is friendly but it’s difficult to communicate with some of them because of their poor English.One advice: Request a final bill from the hotel upon check out and make sure the charges are correct.

For Tokyo, a reasonably sized room with unexpected amenities, such as a refrigerator. The Akasaka neighborhood it is in is great, located midway between the two imperial properties in Tokyo. However the breakfast (in an adjacent Centurion property) was expensive and not that great. Otherwise a good choice, and we would probably stay here again.

Centurion Hotel - Tokyo The standard room are tiny but slightly larger rooms are available.Hotel located in a very vibrant area of Tokyo with many restaurants to choose from and shops close by.Close to Metro and public transport.Reasonable choice for westerners at breakfast but nothing to write home about.

The hotel is very beautiful and located in a very convenient spot - once you know where it is and where everything else is - and apparently a branch building of the larger establishment.It's in close proximity to the subway, no more than 5 minutes walk at a brisk pace, 2-3 if you know how to traverse the numerous short alleys to get to the main road.During the daytime you'd never guess it, but at night, the entire district around the hotel would resemble a drinking or gambling - primarily pachinko - establishment, so during the night it's rather crowded with residents and tourists, who are looking to unwind and have some fun.The hotel is also walking distance to the National Diet building, no more than a mile, which in Tokyo's convoluted streets and walkways would take around 20 minutes to walk to.
user_name:
Craig L
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: We loved the location. Close to Akasaka-Mitsuke station. The area is bustling with quaint cafes and restaurants. Convenience stores are also within reach. I also loved the fact that the hotel offers free onsen experience, unfortunately we didn't have the time to do onsen as we are dead tired going around Tokyo. Breakfast is as good - same menu everyday, but its good enough for us to last until lunch time without getting hungry. The staff is also accommodating. They helped us arrange 2 taxis for Haneda airport. Definitely worth recommending to family and friends.

TOO SMALL for two. The standard double room is incredibly small and unless one really cannot spare anything more than $171/night, I STRONGLY recommend another hotel. The room is smaller than my walk-in closet at home. Only enough room for a queen sized bed and 2 suitcases (keep them closed) plus a small aisle to walk to bed, bath, exit. Bathroom is smaller than the ones on cruise ships (maybe a 4” x 6” space to set your own things on top of counter, but it’s not a smooth counter, slight cupping to hold hotel supplied soaps/lotions). Deeply disappointed and claustrophobic.Even from the third floor one can hear the traffic and conversations from people at ground level. The air conditioning works well. Lighting is great I’m bedroom, not good in shower. Glare from lighting makes it difficult to see one’s reflection for make up and curling hair. Soap products are difficult to dispense more than a few millimeters (one squirt) at a time. Frustrating. Hotel employees are polite. Mostly upset about the lack of space. Online photos are misleading. 200 sq. feet isn’t enough for 2. There isn’t any space on the other side of bed, literally climbing over the other person to get out.) Especially when there isn’t space to unpack and keep suitcases open for two. Probably ok for one person for a couple nights. We had no choice but stay for all 5 without losing our fees paid. TV doesn’t have any English channels. None.

The location is very close to the train lines and small eateries and good drinking spots. The rooms are a bit smaller but decent being in Japan. The best part about this hotel for me is the bed; very comfortable.

We stayed at this hotel for a few nights in August.We were a group of nine adults and all we agree it is a good hotel for visiting Tokyo.The hotel is very close to Akasaka-Mitsuke metro station.Easy to reach from Narita airport.You take the Narita express train and change to metro till Akasaka-Mitsuke station.Same on the way back to the airport.Rooms are small but this is normal in Tokyo.Staff very polite and eager to help.Breakfast good.The breakfast room is sometimes small for all the guests so you need to wait a little to be seated.Some good sushi and italians restaurant nearby.On the third floor there is a convenient laundry room.We all had a good experience.

The good 1) I reached an hour before the check in time of 3 pm and they let me in. Good stuff 2) Wifi is okay 3) The room with king bed was decent 4) Beds were clean and nice The bad 1) The bathroom is super crammed. 2) Breakfast has the same options every day. And it gets super boring. Miso soup. Rice. Curry. Egg. Meatball. Bacon. Sausage. Noodle. Toast. Cereal. Ice coffee. Orange juice. Water. I just described everything they put out every single day in the exact same place. So go figure. 3) The staff just won’t make up your bed if they don’t see a “please clean my room” sticker outside the room. They would just come in, change the towels, clear the waste bin & that’s it. A bit weird. 4) The waste bin is so small, it can only take can drinks. You can’t put in a finished bento takeaway. Again, super weird.

We had a great time at this hotel, the rooms were great, a fairly decent size and attractively decorated. We were a party of 5, I didn’t think the breakfast that great but the rest of the party did. The location is brilliant, close to two metro stations and in a nice area for cafes and restaurants etc with lots of convenience stores. Would stay again.

From the first second I put my legs into the reception, I felt welcome and wanted as a customer. We were politely received and were always greeted with a smile and greeting when we came and went. The rooms are not so big, but clean and tidy. Yakata was available for free use in the rooms. The breakfast was perhaps not very exciting, but gave a decent start to the day. The hotel is very central with several subway lines close. Lots of restaurants around and a nice and relatively quiet area. I would undoubtedly have chosen the same hotel again.

We stayed 3 nights at the Centurion basically just to sleep as we were busy checking out Tokyo all day, every day! The room is small but suited are needs and was an excellent price as Tokyo is generally expensive. Everything necessary plus extras available in the room. The bonus was a cell phone called "Handy". It is basically smartphone that you can take with you on daily outings with Free Internet Access, Unlimited Local Calls, Travel Finds, Brand Promotions and Speed Dial to Hotel Services!!! Seriously valuable use as a tourist!The location is great. Many food choices, close to the subway station and some shopping. We always felt safe in this neighborhood, which is important as a mom traveling with 2 teens alone.The staff was very friendly and attentive. My only complaint would be breakfast. Breakfast was served at the hotel across the street until 10am every morning which was nice to start the day without looking for somewhere to eat. However, the buffet was very limited. Partially cooked scrambled eggs, tiny link sausages, rice, a salad section, toast, and 2 types of cereal. It was the same every day.Other than breakfast, it was a great stay!

Stayed here for 4 nights while we explored Tokyo. The location is excellent, set in a block or two of great restaurants, bars and a family mart. Two subway stations are a couple of minutes walk away, which give you direct access to a total of three subway lines. If you get the discounted 24/48/72 subway pass at the airport (and you should - 1500 yen for three days of unlimited subway is a bargain) the city is at your mercy from here.The staff are incredibly helpfull (sorted a lost phone for me and arranged forwarding of our baggage), and the facilities are very handy - laundromat and a free mobile phone in your room you can borrow were lifesavers.The rooms are small by western standards, but if you look there are cubby noles and spaces where cases can be wedged. Beds are very comfortable, although we ended up with three people in a room with 2 large single beds - so there was some compromise there involving the day bed.Best of all though is the onsen/spa on the second floor. Free to use for guests (male only - the female spa is accross the street). It's absolutely brilliant - my son and I used it three times a day!I like to ring the changes, but all this for around £120 a night for 3? I think I'll be staying again next time I'm in town.

I stayed here during my short 3-day weekend trip in May without much expectations, but i was highly satisfied with my stay. The location is fantastic and you can go to anywhere in Tokyo within a 20min subway ride. I have stayed in many places in Tokyo, but this place is the best. Rooms were decent, no complaints, and the hot bath (Sauna) was great! Although I believe it is only available for men. If you go, check it out and get a relaxing traditional Japanese bath. Lastly, the area the hotel is around has a lot of nice restaurants and it is very tourist friendly so i highly recommend this place.

The rooms themselves are nice, if you are travelling with 2 teenage children though it would be more comfortable to book 2 rooms. We did fit, the beds were comfortable, but we had no room, especially when adding the luggage! The staff were helpful and friendly. We were able to store our luggage on check out, the subway is about 100 metres away, and the limousine bus picks up across the road to go to Narita Airport. So all in all a very convenient location.

I and my family stayed in this hotel in July 18. The checkin was very easy and quickly. The crew was very lovely. Nice!The room, as usually in Japan was small. The breakfast was very simple with few options. The location was amazing. 5 minutes from metro station and several restaurants and stores.

The best thing about The Centurion Hotel Grand Akasakamitsuke was its location. The street its on is lined with restaurants and we just enjoyed exploring the area. The metro station is also close by and so convenient. One negative was the check in process. Although we checked in late at night and were the only ones checking in at the time, it still took so long. Overall though, the staff was very helpful. The rooms were pretty small and like many hotels in Japan there was hardly any counter space in the bathroom. A plus was that the room was really quiet, so quiet that at times I wondered if the hotel was empty. Breakfast was good and served in a nice location. Overall, the great price and location made this hotel a good choice for our family.

It was okay i guess, the bedsheets were stained as we entered the room. The website says that it had a swimming pool, but it didn't! Service was good and 3 different languages they can speak. Japanese, Chinese and English. The only problem was the cleaners of the hotel. They sounded lazy as 75% of the room wasn't cleaned. Everything else was fine tho. 3 Stars.

The hotel is located in the Akasaka district. Close to many restaurants and cafes. Close to the metro station. It's a good place as a base for exploring Tokyo. Breakfast is OK. The room small by western standards is good for Japan. The beds are comfortable. There is an abundance of cosmetics in the bathroom. I didn't however like the aircon in the room. Felt like living in a aquarium with very little fresh air circulation. All in all I'd recommend the hotel for a short stay, 1 or 2 nights.

Loved this hotel. It's tiny just like most hotels in Tokyo. Staff was very helpful. Very centrally located. The subway is a 2 to 3 minute walk. Lots of good restaurants nearby. Amenities were excellent. They provide kimonos, slippers, top of the line organic toiletries. The breakfast was also yummy! Even my picky eaters enjoyed the spread.

Overall 9/10 rating for me.A. Location (10/10)My first time to bring my family to Japan, and had to start with Tokyo. Booked 6 nights stay via Phil Airlines Swingaround package. Just a few minutes walk from Akasaka Mitsuke station as advertised. Hotel has 14 floors, 70+ rooms only. Hotel is sorrounded by low to mid priced restaurants, a 7-11 is right across, Yoshinoya a block away, numerous restos, bars and ramen shops, currency exchange near the Picasso discount store. Bic Camera is at one of the exits of the Akasaka Mitsuke station.About 4 minutes walk away is Hie Shinto Shrine, 15 mins walk is imperial palace grounds (maybe 30 mins walk up to the Edo Gate). Our room package didnt come with breakfast, but no problem as all these stores and restos were right beside the hotel.The street where the hotel is located turns into a busy nightspot come dinner time. Locals and tourists abound. FromBudget to midrange priced restos, they are here. B. Amenities (10/10!!)1. Room Wifi is thru an android smartphone. Pre loaded with google maps and the browser plus a few others. It is a hotspot when used inside the room. I brought it out of the hotel and 4G wifi was working (cant use it as a hotspot anymore), but used the googleMaps app for navigating around tokyo (all train commutes, and lots of walking to visit shops). Free wifi for us. 2 rooms, 2 handsets. Only restriction is you cant makeHandset to handset calls. It does allow you to call japan mobile numbers for free. I called aFriend in Saitama. No charges to ourRoom. Great savings for us.2. Free Onsen for men (8/10)Yes, the hotel has an onsen, free to use for male guests, women have separate onsen on their other building across the street (wife didnt try it, so no feedback3. Audio/Video- Wireless Bluetooth speaker (8/10)JBL in our other room, our room Had another brand, but great sounding too). TV was hdtv as expected, and i watched WORLD CUP games live.4. Lobby lounge areaWe didn’t have breakfast included, so in some days we ate out, other days we bought some food and drinks from the convenience store and ate together as a family at the lounge. No one else was using the lounge/bar/resto in the morning. They do open the lounge and serve all pasta lunch for 1,000 yen; guests cant use the lounge during that time.Night time large TV was showing live world cup games.5. Money exchange machine at the lobby - USD, Euro, Pounds, other currencies- the rate is not the best, as expected, but if you need some yen to top up your Pasmo Card, this is a convenience worth it. The front desk staff will assist you in using the machine, and pay you in yen.6. Beds, sheets, pillows- all good quality. Not familiar with thread count. YUKATA! - traditional japanese robes were provided, great for when you go from your room to the onsen, or want to dress traditional around the hotel.Shampoo, body soap, shaver, thin room slippers, hair dryer, room safe, mini fridge, small bathtub, All provided. 7. The hotel staff - all English speaking, all smiling, all helpful to the guests. Ask them anything and they will make an effort to respond to your query.

This hotel could not have been better for us. First of all, the location was incredible - lots of convenience stores on your doorstep and Akasaka Mitsuke station (metro) a 2 minute walk away. It’s a clean hotel in a great area, lots of amenities (built in phone chargers so handy!) Staff were amazing - friendly, helpful, welcoming. A lot of reviews touch on the small size of the rooms but we stayed in a double with an extra bed and found this was more than enough room for us (probably depends on how long you intend on staying in the room). If you just want somewhere to lay your head while you explore Tokyo, this is perfect.

This is a lovely hotel. The staff is wonderful and helpful, and there are two friendly parakeets that greet you as you enter. As is common of many hotels in Tokyo, the rooms are compact. My husband and I consider ourselves to be light packers-- we traveled with two small backpacks and one carry-on roller suitcase between the two of us, and the room was pretty much at capacity. We had just enough space, but I can imagine that people who pack more heavily, like to spread out, or tend to spend a lot of down time in their hotel rooms when they travel might feel cramped. A couple positives to note that are not noted on this site: there are so many thoughtful little touches that make this hotel great. The best is that they provide a phone that is data-enabled. We found this incredibly helpful for navigation and for searching for little gems while we were out.A couple negatives: I was drawn to this hotel because of the lovely onsen pictures. However, the onsen is men only and tattoos are not allowed. This is common practice for onsens in Japan, but I still felt put-off by that, especially since the pictures are so prominently on the fore of this listing. The thing that really prevented a 5-star rating for me is that the internet was very unreliable on our floor. We got around this somewhat by using the phone they provided in a pinch, but it made it impossible for me to get the work done that I needed to finish-- I ended up going to a cafe because the wifi in my room was so spotty.

I was expecting more, considering the good reviews received. It is just an ordinary business hotel with their usual minuscule room (functional, yes. But depressingly small). The bath is good, but male only in this hotel (female only is in a separate hotel). Breakfast, served in the hotel in front of this one, is awful. A surprise in Japan, where hotel breakfasts tend to be good. Not in this one. Just have it somewhere else.

The hotel and service provided are brilliant, although when we arrived the female spa area was closed so I was unable to use it and cannot comment on how it was. The rooms (even the slightly larger ones- we had booked a superior double with view) are quite small and it is tough to get suitcases open as well in the room. There also wasn;t much of a view from the room even though it claimed there would be. The rooms are very nice though and this area is great for going out to sight-see and also to eat in the evenings. The hotel staff are fantastic and even when we were unable to arrive on our first night stay due to a cancelled flight they were very accommodating. The breakfast included is also good. Each of the rooms has a phone in as well which can be taken out during the day and provides extra internet access for free which we found most useful! Definitely recommend this hotel.
