Ellie T
Brighton, England, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed here twice in April. Our first stay was in a ‘Superior Twin Room’ booked on expedia and our second stay was in a less expensive ‘Superior Double’ booked on agoda. The twin room was significantly larger, but both rooms were fine. There is a very convenient coin laundry at the hotel. The location is excellent as Akasaka is on many metro lines. The street and neighborhood had many restaurants and shops and seemed very safe at all times. We did not try the spa or the breakfast service. The front desk employees were always very helpful at getting taxis etc. Be sure to write down the address as some taxi drivers do not know precisely where the hotel is located.The 7-11 across the street has an ATM and lots of interesting snacks!

The hotel is 5 minutes relax walk to the nearest station which is “Akasaka Mitsuke.”The famous “Ninja Akasaka” restaurant is 5 minutes away also from the station, if you travel with family, this is worth a try.The room is small, but everything is good. We love the location itself, surrounded by good restaurants, and convenient stores. Going to the hotel from Narita hotel, if you have bulky luggages, it is better to take the airport limousine bus, which is 3,100 ¥, it takes 2 hours. Go down at Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu, and across the road, toward the Bic Camera building facing the hotel, and 5 minutes walk from there going to the hotel. We tried also the train going back to the airport, we used the sky liner train, it took us only 1 hour and 10 minutes.Since we have lots of luggages, we sent most of our luggages 2 days ahead of time to airport, since our flight was early in the morning and the airport limousine bus can’t accomodate with our schedule. Love this hotel location and will refer to others to choose this hotel.

Bedroom are tiny small, not enough plugs to use. The staff barely speaks english. One night we had fire alarm going at 1am we all evacuate but nothing was communicates. The bath are not inside the hotel but ouSide on another street. The baths are opened 24/7 but you can only go for 1 h

We arrived to our room (booked for 2 adults+2 children)and had requested a baby cot. There was barely place to stand in the room after the cot was included. Upon complaining to front desk, they said room was 14sq.m. and the next big room available is 16sq.m. but not tonight, from tomorrow and the other room 24sq.m. available one day after that. So I made additional payment to move to 16sq.m. room one night later. The 16sq.m room (which was in a building on the opposite side of the road from the original hotel) was double the size of the 14sq.m one and when I asked to stay in this as it was adequate for my family, they would not refund the extra amount i paid for the 24sq.m..so I decided to move into the largest room ..since I had already paid. So for a 4-night stay, I had to stay in 3 separate rooms and check-in/check-out as many times. On final check-out we left the room at 11:30am instead of the official 11am time and I was charged an extra 4000jpy for late check-out which was unfair. If they had not falsely labelled their single 14sq.m. room as suitable for 4 guests, we would have had a more comfortable stay. Location was very good with convenience shops around and Akasaka-Mitsuke station a 4 minute walk away. Their Handy mobile device for free usage was also very welcome. Yamato luggage service was also available directly from the front desk.

So be prepared to get a surprise as you enter the room, since you barely take a step and the room gets over. Yes, I have traveled around the world and this was one of the smallest room I have been too. At first I thought they had mistaken my booking as I had requested for a double bed but no it was the right room. One turn and you can fall from the bed, the bathroom again is a arms stretch length, the hairdryer is as slow as it could be. No place to keep your suitcase, no English news channel, and the breakfast is as pathetic as it could be plus it’s not in the same building, you have to cross and go to another building.The only saving grace is that it’s centrally located and a minute walk to the station.

We had a very large room with a fantastic view. Great amenities! Lovely and clean and quiet, we stayed here for our last couple of nights in Tokyo and could have happily stayed longer. Good location close to transport and restaurants. Breakfast was good. Staff friendly and helpful :)

Nice hotel, well located, pleasant rooms. Fair in price. The area is nice, with lots of restaurants and near the metro station. It is easy to find. Reception is small and does not offer airport transfers.

We booked on line, the centurian is a fine hotel in Akasaka, but there were things they didn't mention in booking. You actually book on line at the centurian and then sent to an inferior hotel across the laneway. The difference happens to be whether you book into the Hotel Centurian Grand OR the Hotel Centurian Vintage. We booked the Grand and ended across the lane in the Vintage. That may or may not matter to some fellow travellers, but it must be said we got an inferior room in a hotel we didn't book. Once all was over, we could not get a cup of coffee in the morning, 1...because the restaurant wasn't open in the hotel we were given, and 2....the grand hotel didn't recognise us as patrons. Try and get a coffee around that area between 7.00 and 11.30am, impossible!! The Hotel clerks etc, tried a bit, but bowing and saying they were sorry doesn't make up for the charges we paid and not being able to get a cup of coffee.

We started 4 nights at the end of our trip and room is small (as advertised)but very comfortable bed and everything included was good. The free Onsen was a real huge benefit and a very nice addition when you walk so much in the city as it’s 24hr and a free addition.

We stayed 2 nights in Tokyo after spending 10 days up in Northern Japan Skiing - the location is fantastic especially if you were like us and pressed for time. The Subway station is close by and there is huge variety of shops, bars, and restaurants literally right outside your door step. The onsen baths are on the 2nd Floor and are great to soak after a day of sightseeing - although it feels as though its set up for the local businessmen who chose to stay in the city overnight as always had confusion at the desk about inhouse guest being able to use the onsen free of charge. Overall we would go back - and yes the rooms are a box but it is Tokyo after all and the hotel is extremely clean which all you can ask for at a budget hotel.

This hotel was good, the bed was nice and big and the spa facilities were great. However the shower wasn't very powerful and during breakfast the space wasn't big enough so we had to wait around 15 minutes to be seated. The location was perfect, with the station just around the corner.

Like all Japanese hotels, the rooms are tiny. However, it’s been compensated by the cleanliness and modern features of the room. The toiletries were of superb quality. The water pressure is good. There are also a lot of places to eat around the hotel. And it is just a block away from the Akasaka Mitsuke station. I will stay in this hotel once again when I come back to Tokyo.

I was stay 2 nights in this hotel with my friends and it was pleasant stay. The location were great, just five minutes walking from Akasaka-Mitsuke station. The room is clean and comfortable. Small but cozy considering I've been to a smaller room. The bathroom also clean which I consider a crucial part of a hotel. The amenities quite complete although there weren't any bottle of mineral water but it's fine because convenient store like Lawson or Family Mart is near enough by walking.The heating is working, thank God. It's snowing on our first day so it's very helpful for us. Overall, I like this hotel and I would recommend it.

The best thing I love about this hotel is its bed, so soft and comfortable. My room was nice and clean, it has a large glass widow, however, I did not like much the city view, so boring but as I choosed a city hotel, this is reasonable.. The food is great and amzingly tasty. I feel addictived with their dishes.

We were let down by our Air BnB at the last minute (the first and last time we ever try and book with them) so had to find a hotel in Tokyo over New Year and we lucked out! Now this is Tokyo and we found the Centurion which is right in the centre of a great district - on the Ginza line which is the best for everything. The hotel was fully booked so no choice of room and you have to know that in all of Tokyo hotel rooms are small - be ready for that. However the bed was so so so comfortable - the rooms were impeccably clean - the service was amazing - breakfast was very good - there is a very cheap laundry room you can use. The area had so many great bars (make sure you visit Luthers just up the street) and restaurants. As I said connections are great from here. However as in all of Japan service is so good and everyone works so hard to ensure that everything is top quality - the staff here were excellent and helpful.

Booked 2nights,Hotel loopy is small but adequate in terms of size and seating area,check in/out process was smooth and staff were helpful and English is manageable,Breakfast is served in there sister hotel just opposite to the hotel(1/2 min.walk) and quality/variety is adequate to start your day,good coffee.2elevators,Room is medium in terms of size but with adequate lay-out,bed is comfy abit out dated but clean,tea maker available in the room but w/o amenities,fridge is empty for your personal use,toilet/shower stocked with amenities and clean(good house keeping) shower pressure is nice.Hotel location is prime 3min walk to Akasaka-mitsuk station,plenty of cafes and restaurants around.

Location:Just 2 mins walk from the Akasaka-Mitsuke subway. Lots of eateries, convenient stores and a drug store at the corner.checkin:Checkin was superb. We arrived at 10 am and although official check in was 2 pm, we were allowed to proceed to our room free of charge.Room:Spacious and clean. Mattress was of high quality slumberland and comes with 2 pillows each. Beside the standard toiletries, what we love most is the addition Organic Cleanser oil, Face wash and Toner. Laundry is on the 3rd floor and per wash is 200 yen. Need to buy the liquid detergent from the reception at 100 yen. Men onsen is on the 2nd floor but for ladies need to walk to another building just behind the hotel.

The hotel is surrounded by restaurants, shops and convenience stores. The MTR station and the airport limousine stop are only a few minutes' walk from the hotel. The buffet breakfast was in another building across the street, there wasn't much varieties and they served the same food every morning. The room was clean but small and the staff were friendly. I requested for a quiet room on a high floor and that was exactly what I had, couldn't hear any noise from the busy street below.

Nice area, around upscale apartments and expats. Staff were very attentive, providing additional amenities upon request. Very large bed, which allows a couple to spread out. A great hotel to end a trip to Japan!

Room was clean. Very accomodating staff. We stayed for just one night but our experience was favorable. Even without prior reservation, they accomodated us on the spot on a stormy night. Thank you, Centurion!

Great location. A lot of small restaurant on the hotel alley and very close to subway. The spa and sauna on 2nd floor is a plus facility for free as a hotel guest. Room a bit small but I guess is a tokyo standart size.

Stayed at one of the Superior Double with Queen+rollaway for 3 at the main tower.Room small but clean and tidy. Provide good quality cleansing oil, toner, face wash, and lotion in room. Located in a convenient tourist area, the hotel is surrounded by all types of restaurants. Complimentary bath and spa, but not recommend the female section which is located off site, small and unclean. It is said that the male section is ok with clear water bath and milky bath.

The hotel situated at a good Subway Location and with access to many areas. The Superior Room we had is much better than the normal size. However, with the standard of hotel, they do not provide tea bags as other hotels. The carpet in our room had a humid smell or other things are all good! The curtain does not have black out and is bright in the morning.There is a nearby 24 hours seafood grill restaurant is a must try! And lastly, the way they present with all other chargeble does not provide friendly gesture.

The hotel is well maintained and the front desk was very helpful. Spoke English very well.The location of this hotel has many restaurants to choose from and all in walking distance. For transportation we used the train easy to figure out navigate. Most signs in in Japanese and in English on the trains.

Stayed for 6 nights in August in what was billed on the booking site as an "economy double". The room was small even by Japanese business hotel standards. Travelling as a couple with only carry-on size suitcases, we had difficulty putting our things away and having clear access to the bed, desk, bathroom, etc. That said, the quality of the amenities was high. The bed was a double (not a semi-double) and was large enough for us. In fact, the bed and pillows were remarkably comfortable. Staying in summer we were concerned with heat, however the air conditioning in the room was very effective. The room has a small fridge and a large TV (not sure about channels, we didn't turn it on). We had only positive encounters with the friendly, multilingual staff. Room cleaning every day made us feel well cared for.The only real downside for us is that we didn't love the neighbourhood. It's easily accessible by subway with two stations on different lines in a short walking distance and there are lots of restaurants and other businesses in the area but it felt like a bustling business district and not a community.

I did a lot of research in determining where my family would stay when visiting Tokyo for the first time, and decided on the Centurion. I liked the location, as it was only a few minutes walk to the nearest train station, which was a block away. There were convenience stores readily available, as well as great food nearby. The room itself was the "family style," which had decent space and was priced fairly for midrange, downtown Tokyo stays. I recommend this hotel for families with kids. The double beds for my husband and I took up the entire half of the room, with a small aisle to walk, and a set of bunk beds for (1) our son and (2) our luggage. The bathroom was great! I was expecting something tiny, but it was sectioned off into a vanity and toilet area (fancy bidet style toilet), and a closet shower/soaking tub. We needed to ship our luggage to our next hotel, and the front desk was able to understand enough English to accomplish this. Between my husband, myself, and the workers at the Centurion, we were able to cobble together enough English to make our stay make sense. I had to laugh at the constant stream of Jazz Muzak playing on the speakers in the room (you can turn it off, but why? It's hilarious). Then, in the restaurant where breakfast is served, we had American top 40. Interesting mix! And on the food note: breakfast is served buffet style in the hotel across the street, and with enough offerings to make both Japanese and Western guests happy. I am a picky eater, and I was as happy as my vegetarian-but-adventurous-eating husband. The restaurant had a cute set up as well, as if you are eating in someone's living room. There are birds in the hobby who sing you a welcome as well. The outdoor ambiance of the hotel is wonderful! You cannot hear anything from your neighbors. When approaching the hotel, you're greeted by string lights, trees, and a patio to eat or drink on. Very well lit. Only issues... peeling wallpaper in the bathroom, moldy floor in bathroom (with distinct mildew smell). I had also been misinformed that this hotel was accepting of guests with tattoos, so I made the reservation specifically so that my husband (who has large back tattoos) could use the gorgeous spa and enjoy his first onsen experience. But they had signs all over that floor that stated tattoos were not acceptable. He asked, just to make sure, and confirmed with the front desk that NO TATTOOS ARE ALLOWED IN THE SPA. Someone had mentioned in a review that this is a "sex district." Uh, no. Showing some skin is certainly a way to sell products. Every night we stayed there, my son averted his eyes (still in the "girls have cooties" phase of being a preteen) from the girl standing on the corner in her bikini, short shorts, and 5 inch heels. I still couldn't tell you what she was selling. We hustled past as soon as possible! Otherwise, it is a busy district, but no noise was audible in our room. There were plenty of restaurants, bars, pharmacies, and conbini near us. And no signs of this being a "sex district." My big negative for staying there was that the women and men had completely different bathing areas... women have to walk down a dark alley to a completely different building, where they are given an hour to do their business. Not to say the bathing/spa experience was negative, just that it wasn't in the building I was staying in. Additionally, I don't believe it was an onsen, as it was constantly referred to as a spa, nor did I see any paperwork on the onsen water quality anywhere. So this could be classified as a sento?

Can't speak highly enough. Was allowed an early check in. The staff were very friendly. Printed some documents for me at no cost. The budgies in the lobby were a cute touch. The room was fairly standard size for Japan. Yes it's small but it was bigger than the previous one I stayed in and how much time do you need to spend in your room anyway? As it is quite new the room decor is also good. The even had a little boom box speaker but I couldn't work out how to connect it to my phone. The location is great. Not sure why people say middle of red light district. It's safe, there are good shops and price was very reasonable Will be booking for next visit.

We made the mistake of staying in this hotel for three nights and regret it. It's bang on the night life area where you get propositioned as you walk. They have two building and we were given to stay in the building which appeared like a sex den- such of the décor and vibe of the place. We asked to change and they refused. The check out is at 11am and we requested to extend by couple of hours and they asked for more than 4000 yen for the same. It is located well and well connected. It is certainly not meant for family t stay even for a minute.

Great location (just a few minutes from the Akasaka statio), rooms are clean, comfortable and the amenities are just incredible ( they are full sized, and include items like face masks). The staff is helpful and well trained. Great hotel for a great price.

This is a nice hotel with lots of eatery around it but for a family with a teenager the room is relatively small after putting two laugages! And this is also the first time I encounter a hotel room in Japan that shower curtain is mouldy! Yes moulds and we feedback to the hotel they got it clean next day ! Another thing to feedback was the dustbin in the toilet was smaller than the slipper - so for 3 pax to use can u imagine how were the bin will look like ! Venue of hotel is Good but you can find more convenience place in tern of travelling.

A must visit destination love the city enjoyed the food the hotel was accommodating and love the bed & covers. The people are amazing and very kind and nice. Definitely coming back and visit other places in japan.

We had the family room with two queen size beds and two bunk beds. There was not much room for luggage but it was as I had expected. The location was really good with three subway stations at walking distance so it was easy to get to almost anywhere in Tokyo. There also were loads of small restaurants on the streets near the hotel and it was really pleasant to walk around the area in the evening with the kids. The breakfast was quite limited but there was toast, cereals, bacon and scrambled eggs in addition to all the Japanese stuff.

The hotel room is small, as is common in Tokyo, but very clean, and the beds are very comfortable. Bonus: the hotel includes a nice spa for men only, as women have to walk to their sister hotel down the street. It is free of charge for hotel guests. The hotel is very well located, close to Akasaka Mitsuke metro station, but more importantly within walking distance of lots of restaurants and shops. It is overall very god value, given their reasonable rates.

Outstanding central location, value and cleanliness! Within walking distance of Akasaka palace. Within 20 minutes walk to Roppongi, Ginzaand about 30 minutes from Harajuku. Excellent restaurants and cafes close by. Friendly and attentive English speaking staff. The automatic toilet is a dream and the water pressure was something I've never experienced in Texas. Japanese breakfast is free but anyone interested in a Western breakfast can slow walk to the Tully's, Dotour or McDonalds within 15 minutes of the hotel. Ps:$20 taxi ride to Tokyo station is worth it if you are a large family and have check-in luggage.

Stayed here last week in separate rooms with my family of six (6) for three (3) nights. My first impression of our room was quite small yet very clean and cozy. I love how the bathroom is well maintained, clean and with complete toiletries especially for the ladies. There are medium sized bottled shampoo, conditioner, body wash, lotion, toner, facial wash, cleansing oil, facial masks and lots of combs, mini hair ties, cotton buds, razors, toothbrushes with mini toothpaste, cleansing pads etc. On the bed there are three (3) kimonos that you can wear great for selfies. :P The bed is warm, soft and comfy thus gives me a peaceful night sleep after a long tiring day. This place is superb for people who are backpackers / light packers. We have a lot of stuffs that's why we can barely move. About the hotel, it is handicapped friendly because I saw some foreigner went her way in the elevator and inside there are buttons for the handicapped. The staffs are very accommodating and you can understand their english well. Kudos to the female japanese receptionist who immediately responded and fixed it right away when the travel agency booked our rooms in separate buildings. I find the hotel's main lobby too narrow and it can get a little crowded if there are other tourist around waiting since there's limited seating capacity. Across the main building is where you can have your free buffet breakfast. It's the other Centurion Grand building with many chairs and tables.There are many japanese restaurants outside the hotel and only few japanese restaurants have take outs. You can easily spot a convenience store outside of the hotel just along the street. This place is very accessible, since it's just a few minutes away from the station. Overall, it's worth your money. I had fun staying here with my family.

the hotel is a few minute walk maybe 1 minute to the akasaka-mitsuke station. Lots of restaurants, convenience stores, mcdo, travelex ,tokyu plaza nearby. staff spoke english well, very helpful and informativethe hotel room is small but complete with the amenities you need, with organic toiletries, laundry machine. will surely be back

Stayed in the premium double room with one king and one sofa bed as we had 3 people. It was pretty hard to find a room for 3 in Tokyo for a reasonable price. Even though the room was quite small, we barely had space to open 3 luggages on top of the sofa bed, the room and hotel was really clean. Instead of the main building where the reception, our room was in the other building facing the main building called Vintage.Best thing about this hotel is the subway access and huge number of restaurants in the area. We ran out of meals to try all the good food in the area that we had supper after 12 midnight everyday. Ramen shops are open till pretty late. Akasaka-Mitsuke station has both Ginza and Marunouchi Line that can basically get you to any of the famous attractions/areas in Tokyo. I would suggest taking the Narita Access (a bus service) from Ginza station to and fro Narita Airport that costs 1,000yen, instead of traveling by subway which will require 2/3 transfers or the Limousine bus that costs 3,000yen recommended by the hotel concierge. From Ginza station it's just a few stops to Akasaka Mitsuke station, and a 4 minute walk to the hotel from the station.

We booked into the Centurion Hotel Grand Akasaka with our family of 5 (2 teenagers and an 11 year old) and we impressed from day one. The rooms are very clean and well set up with an abundance of toiletries, equipment and facilities. The staff are very accomodating and reaponsive particularly as we are not fluent in Japanese. The morning breakfast service is high quality with a great selection of both Japanese and western dishes in the buffet. Our rooms we in the Vintage hotel across the road from the main hotel and our floor was tastefully decorated with an impressive wallpapered hallway of Van Goghs' Starry Night. Very cool. While the rooms are cosy by western standards, we all fit comfortably and had no complaints. Great location with many dining options within a short stroll and metro train station only 100m away. Great hotel for our first stay in Japan. Recommend.

It's very good location, near subway..and the environment just very warmfull. The room was ok, not too big for 3 adult people. The bathroom was too small but it was good and very clean. The room was very clean too. Breakfast was good, they have varieties menu every 2 days. And the food was good. This hotel location was in very good location. Very near to subway. Surrounded with a lot off restaurant. I was very satisfied I stay in this hotel when visit Tokyo for 5 days. The price was ok too. Very good hotel at all :)

+Hotel very close to the akasaka -mitsuke station(maybe 150 meter from the exit station).The rooms are not very large (in line with Japanese standards)but very clean and comfortable.- Breakfast can be greatly improved

I ve expected the hotel rooms in Japan to be smaller than many other countries. I stayed in a room that was meant for 3 people and the bed placements were quite weird, but we managed. Along the street there are a lot of Centurion Hotel extensions. I stayed in the new building of Centurion hotel called the Vintage. It is actually right across the older building. So if you want to wash your clothes, you have to go to the other building. The same goes with the vending machines. The nice thing about this hotel is, it is located smack down in the middle of two train stations. The closest is Akasaka Mitsuke which has the Ginza and Marunochi lines. While the other one is Akasaka which has the Chiyoda line. Another one is Nagatacho station, which serves the Hanzomon line. The street is also dotted with Family marts, small restaurants, 7-11, vending machines, and Picasso which sells everything from electronics to socks. AS i said the hotel and rooms are small but it is clean. You dont have to worry about bathrooms, hot water, free wi-fi and amenities. They do not provide free mineral water like in many other big hotels.

The hotel is 5 mins from Akasaka Mitsuke metro, surrounded by scores of restaurants and bars. Standard small rooms and bath, but good in its price category. The onsen is excellent, but for men only. Reception has some English ability most of the time. Breakfast includes simple western food

This hotel was located in close proximity to the subway station. Lots of food options around. The staff was friendly and breakfast was included in our price. The nightly rate was affordable and the rooms were more than adequate to explore Tokyo. I would definitely stay there again. The breakfast area is small. I liked the fact that you can get free drinks in the lobby area. The rooms had a refrigerator.

Paid more for a standard double with breakfast. Room was comfortable - bed was full-size, enough space for small amount of luggage for two, usual good shower/bath, had a window with view of street. Staff were helpful with maps and information.Breakfast room too small- needs reorganizing with smaller furniture. Had to wait 15 minutes to sit with my wife.Hotel is close to both Akasaka metro stations, especially Akasaka Mitsuke. Many restaurants in different price ranges in same street. Next parallel street up also has international-type coffee shops e.g. Tullys - and restaurants - Chinese, Italian etc. The Bondi cafe in the Biz tower near Akasaka metro has the best (expensive) coffee.

We stayed here for 2 nights with our 2 children - 15 and 13 years. It is a very good hotel in a great location - 2 minute walk to subway. The hotel is quite modern - rooms are compact but not ridiculously small. A bonus is a free onsen - one for women ( about 1 minute walk away) and men can use theirs 24/7 as in hotel. Breakfast was good - decent non Asian breakfast if you are over noodles and need toast. We have stayed in another hotel in Akasaka but this one would be my preference. Staff speak good english and free wifi - plus in the heart of many good cafes/restaurants.

We booked this hotel last minute and couldn't have been happier. The staff was incredibly welcoming, friendly and helpful. The rooms were clean and cozy with large bathrooms including great products. Plus, the location is great - it's a quick 5 minute walk to the nearest subway station. Highly recommed!

Everything was Amazing, From the great welcoming and helping Staff to location to Breakfast and fountain drinks all day long. Room is clean and having a lot of useful accessories Advise: take the bigger room with a slight higher price.

This Boutique hotel is walking distance from the Akasaka Mitsuke train station. don't take any taxi as we mistakenly did and it took us much, much farther and had to painfully walk back with helpful japanese gentlemen. With sputtering nihonngo,they understood our predicament. The hotel is super clean just like its country. Though the bedroom is very small, the bed was white and fresh as snow. We slept better than the princess. The breakfast is delicious with their best known Japanese sticky rice. With two kinds of bread, butter and assorted choice of jams, eggs, fish, sausages, appetisers, juice, coffee or tea.One can also partake of coffee and juice all day long from the lobby.Brand new showers and warm toilet seats make an interesting point to our stay. We stayed most of the day going around Tokyo and my husband attending conferences so the scarcity of space was not a big deal. A little pricey though for the p29,000 we paid for three nights.

Best thing about this hotel is all the extras it offers in terms of free beverages at reception, access to sauna [on site for men and 1 block away for women] and the biggest ever array of toiletries in the bathroom!! It is close to Akasaka tube station. The reception staff are very helpful. Although the room was very very small, it was good value as far as Tokyo hotels go. The negative point about it is that the area has a very busy nightlife. Working girls and their minders stand opposite the hotel every night. However they were in no way a bother to passers-by.

This hotel was a welcome relief from an Airbnb gone bad. The room was large enough for a family of 4 (great bunks for the kids) and the adult beds were very comfortable. The shower is heavenly! Staff were efficient and helpful. Great location, very close to a metro station and loads of dining options. We would choose this again.

This hotel is located in a central location in Akasaka, close to the Tokyo Palace and a major food area! We opted for a regular room non smoking so a little tight but we managed. I swear I got closer to my fiancé because the room was so small! The best thing about this hotel is their service! We planned an open trip to allow for flexibility in our decision making at the risk of possibly not getting what we want. We wanted to eat at Sushi Saito and front desk called for days to acquire information while keeping me in the loop as I was out and about. Unfortunately they could not get a reservation for us for the date we wanted at the Saito's. They need months in advance reservation as they are world renowned! The front desk personnel did not give up and tried every other Michelin Star restaurant in Tokyo. Like Saito's they need advanced reservations. We were bummed when Centurion personnel could not get us our reservations but at the same time surprised at how thorough they were with our requests. Going that extra mile wins me over for the next time I go to Tokyo!

First time in Tokyo. We randomly chosed this hotel.It is very close to Akasaka metro line, 3mn walking distance.The room is not big for 2 people but convenient. You have everything you need in a hotel facilities. Breakfast is included ( fish in the morning is yummy ). Besides you have complimentary access to the onsen located on the 2nd floor but only reserved to men. Just wear your kimono and get there. The personnel is kind. Speak very few english but we got ourself understood.I recommend the place.

This is less specious and expensive but it's normal in Tokyo. This hotel has very modern amenities and staffs are very helpful. I enjoyed my stay. There are nice restaurants around the hotel. Good location.

Going through endless expensive hotels looking for a bargain and this one jumped out, what a lovely place, not just facilities and furnishings but location as well. Free breakfast included which is nice free drinks including fizzy coffee and soups, free spa for naked men only mostly serious business types (Japanese) and staff are great very helpful although one after asking for a good Teppanyaki restaurant said I don't speak English ffs lol, but anything. You ask for within reason is sorted and check out the the throne room !!! When booking make sure you ask for double bed and NON smoking as they still allow it there, but if you ask they will help and change for you if they can, they also rent pocket wifi which is a must 500yen a day well worth it

I decided to try something different on my last trip to Tokyo, and forgo the large, int'l hotel and instead stay at ar a nice enough small hotel in an interesting neighborhood. Akasaka-Mitsuki fit the bill very well as a happening and interesting neighborhood, and the hotel did great, too.The rooms are small (at least mine was), but fully adequate with a very nice bathroom, good tv, excellent wifi, and all-round coziness.The breakfast was decent, and there are places nearby if you want something more.A Japanese bath is on the second floor, and it's free for hotel guests. Fantastic.

A very good hotel in Tokyo. Very well located. You always find place to go eating or drinking a glass after a day visiting or working in Tokyo.The bedroom are clean and ok but are very small for europeen people. Nothing special in Japan.

So the thing is the hotel is very well located, it is very nice and has quite comfortable rooms. The service on the other hand is very poor. I received wrong directions and it wasnt a language issue becaus she drew on a map and it was a completely different street. They also made a huge fuss with calling a taxi to the airport even though i informed them at 10 am that i would need a big cab at 9pm. They were unableto organize one so they just told me to take 2 small ones (total cost 16 000 yen) and refused for a while to call me 1 small one when i insisted we would fit. We did fit and issue was resolved but not thanks to their help since they just spent most of the time pushing the issue to someone else.If u want a stress free stay i dont recommend but if u are alone and dont care so much it's quite ok.

I can't say any fault on this Japan's trip and our stay at Centurion Grand Hotel for six nights. The staff are always welcome and trying to help whatever you have requested for. Hotel is located in a very convenient location where few minutes walk to metro subway station, Akasaka-Mitsuke, which is related next to the big store, bic camera. You can get every things that you need in there, and can do the last minutes shopping. Lots of restaurant are surrounded so we won't bother eating breakfast at the hotel. The breakfast was not bad as we tried for one day.But prefer to eat local food so we eat out rest of the days. It was raining so the hotel staff borrowed us an umbrella, without even asking. The hotel provide you with free wifi and you can rent the pocket wifi for 500 yen a day at the counter which is cheaper than renting in the airport. You can ask how to go the way and they can even provide you with information sheets and map. The room was very clean and the bed was very comfortable. It was provided with full sets of facial cleaners such as cleaning oil, forming cleaners, lotion and face masks that made me very happy. Using electric toilet was a bit different and shampoo, conditioner and shower gel, hair dryer were all provided. Overall, it was an pleasant stay and we will be back again.

The Centurion is one of the newer hotels in Akasaka. It is only a couple of years old, and it gets better each time I stay. It has begun catering to western travelers as well as the large number of Chinese. Rooms are small, but very nice, with English on some channels (which is rarer than you would think in Akasaka). Breakfast is small, mostly Asian, but with cereal, bread and soups if you don't want the Asian option. Access is given to the spa, but tattoos aren't welcome unless they can be covered.

Yes the rooms are small but this Tokyo. The hotel is immaculately clean and essentially brand new. The toiletries are great and include two face masks so you can look nice. Coffee and tea in the room too along with bottled water. Super close to Akasaka Mitsuke station. Go out the exit for Bic camera and hang a left out of the station (Excel Hotel should be to your back on the opposite side of the station entrance. Walk up one block make a right, walk a block and then hang a left. Hotel is a minute walk away and should be on your right. Note, there is another Centurion hotel in the distance so be sure confirm which property you have booked. Japanese breakfast was a decent spread and yes the area is a little small but you're allowed to take it back to your room if you like. Best value bonus for MEN is the small but FREE public bath in the hotel. It has two big hot tubs, a cold plunge, and a dry sauna. Nice toiletries and it's immaculately clean and they have ice water to cool you down. Make sure you take a thorough shower before be getting into the public bath and rinse off before re-entering the tubs after sweating it out in the sauna. Note, the English explanation paper is slightly confusing. The bath is open 24 hours a day. Hotel guests should wear the in-room slippers and the yukata (looks like pajamas) to the spa. They will give you a towel there. For ladies you must use the bath at the Centurion hotel a quick walk away. Ask the staff at front desk for a coupon. Please don't be upset that facilities aren't coed or matching, this is Japan, it's cultural. Space is at a premium in Tokyo so the fact that there is free access to both male and female guests is huge. Regular people pay a minimum charge of 1200 yen for an hour. Fantastic option in Tokyo!

By far the most unhelpful reception staff I have met in Japan thus far. Perhaps they were having a bad day, but it was only 9am or so and I had to ask three or four times for some directions. Each time I was shooed away with a non-answer along the lines of, 'just get the subway'.That incident aside, I was very pleased with the price and the stay generally. A pleasant surprise was the quality of the facilities, including a lounge area on the ground floor which offered free self-serve soft drinks, tea and coffee, and what looked to be cup soups.

Very affordable hotel in a convenient location. Very close to many metro stations. Lots of stores and food near the hotel. Walking distance from different nightlife districts if you stay past the last train.

We agree with the most reviews previously posted, it's located very conveniently, a lot of restaurants, night shops and massage parlors in the neighbourhood. Great vibe in the evening. The subway station is connected by a few subway lines. In terms of accomodation, the room size was okay, and the bathroom was better than expectated: Japanese style toilet and little cute bath cabin. Furthermore, the room was clean and they provided a lot of tools for your usage: masks, skin lotion and even chargers for androids and IOS systems. What we liked the most, was the 'public' bath house on the second floor (male only, for ladies it's in different building), which was free for the hotel guests. So relaxing after a day of sightseeig!A few minor points which they could improve: not enough tables for guests during breakfast time, only limited tv channels and the room curtains could not block the sun light entirely. These were only a couple points, but it would not stop us to stay here again.

This was a perfect base for Tokyo. It is like 2 half blocks from the subway (you can definitely roll your luggage here) in a neighborhood with TONS of restaurants just outside. However, inside it's quiet and easy to sleep. The room is very small. Like one side of the bed is against the wall, and the other side is nearly against the window. However, they have designed the furniture pretty well so that you have space to stash away things. Somehow they fit a bathtub which is awesome. Breakfast was solid Japanese (rice, fish, veggies). I think there were other things now but I didn't pay good attention (like bread and cereal). There's a coffee and juice machine free all day and they'll rent you a pocket wifi for a very reasonable rate (I think it was like $5 for 2 days but I can't honestly remember). The amenities really are good too. I read that in previous reviews and thought, "what in the world are they talking about?" And upon arrival found our room stocked with those facial masks in addition to the usual Asian things like free slippers, comb, toothbrush, etc... That's not a reason to stay here but the face masks are fun to use!

This is the first time I've been to Japan and I was very nervous coming here. This place was amazing. The hotel was nicer than the nicest hotel I've stayed at in the states and I've stayed at my fair share of 5 star hotels. The location is VERY easy to get to from Narita airport. You just hop on the limo bus, get off at excel hotel akasaka and walk the two blocks to the grand centurion. The hotel has amazing amenities. Especially if you are a girl. Shampoo, conditioner, face wash, toner, face masks, toothbrush, toothpaste. There is really no reason for you to bring anything. The bed is very comfortable. My only grievance is the pillows could be better. Free breakfast. Free snacks and drinks. Really it was an amazing hotel and the location was right next to two train lines and tons of AWESOME restaurants. The front desk spoke very good English as well. Would definitely stay here again!!

The hotel is small but this is Tokyo so I have no complaint. Everything looks new and lovely. The room is tiny (just fit for 1 person) but very clean, quiet and equipped with basic amenities. Face masks are even available! The price is reasonable, pity that I didn’t have time to enjoy the spa (offered once for guests to try). The metro station is just within few minutes of walk and there are lots of eateries around. Overall, I really enjoy my stay in this hotel.

This hotel is located perfectly .. with two stations within minutes of walking...and excellent street full of choices to eat..The hotel itself, was spot less clean with modern interiors and helpful staff...this hotel just makes everything convenient for you. you can get the pocket wifi for 500 yen a day.. the breakfast is some thing they'll need to work on.. three days that we stayed there... the menu for breakfast remained the same... anyways we looked at other options close by as well.. as there are plenty.the hotel is wonder and so is their service... one must stay here.. PS: they upgraded as (on our honeymoon) and also gifted us a small hand towel...(odd but thoughtful).

Convenient location. The room was not big but very cozy. The japanese style breakfast was great, everything was so delicious. I would definitely recommand this place to my friends!Special note for the super good service. Everything is set up in the most considerable fashion , staff is all friendly and nice.

I picked this hotel for our family trip as they are one among the few hotels in Tokyo that offers Queen size bed, we need a huge bed as my little one co sleeps with us. Hotels in Tokyo are really small so we were really not expecting a lot from this hotel but the room has surprisingly enough space to spread out our luggage. The location is perfect as there's a lot of restaurants nearby, plus 7-11 just in front of the hotel where we get our midnight snacks! It's very close to Akasaka Mitsuke Station and accessible to major tourist destinations.

We stayed in a family room with 2 adults and 2 teenagers (2 double beds). The room was tiny but definitely good enough for our needs, it was well priced. There was a washing machine in the room which was not clearly advertised but it made the holiday a lot easier. The hotel also has rooms for larger families. The hotel was clean with great reception staff. It was only 2 mins walk from 2 different subway lines. The breakfast was not great but it was sufficient.

Stayed 6 nights for business. Location was great! Just 1 minute from Exit 10. Bed was comfortable, full range of amenities. Not many choices for breakfast and only few seats available. Overall the stays were great and staffs were polite.

Very convenient location close from the underground (2 minutes from Akasakasuke lines G and M and 6 minutes from Akasaka line C).Easy to access from Tokyo Central and accordingly from both airports (especially Haneda with Keikyu line if you go to Roppongi and take a cab there - it took us 1 hour from picking up our luggages)Rooms are clean and confortable but very tinyBreakfast is deceptive: very restricted choice and limited number of seatsStaff does its best effort to helpPossibility to purchase pocket wi-fi at the reception (500¥) if you want to stay connected during your visitsAll in all if you are looking for a place to sleep and if your goal is to visit it is a very good price/quality relation when considering the cost of hospitality in Tokyo.

The front desk staff were excellent, helped us book restaurants and taxis. The room was spacious and well presented. Shower was excellent which is always important! Breakfast was ok....a little light on selection. But staff were very helpful. I'd go back.

I am about to check out after 4 days in this really good hotel!Location is superb! Right by the tube station at Akasaka Mitsuke, a popular interlocking streets of restaurants, bars, and small shops and other smaller hotels. You can not starve here I can assure you! The choice is overwhelming which I loved!! And the food is superb! We are talking SUPERB and the prices are relatively cheap compare to ginza etc where the area is too touristy to my liking! The hotel is a boutique one, but the biggest in the area, the spa is really good! Although be prepared that in Japanese culture, people are naked in spas so this was a bit awkward for us Brits/EuropeansThe rooms are the size of a boat cabin, you are in Japan after all so just accept the fact that rooms are tiny! Once you accept this, you will realise that rooms at the centurion grand are bigger than others! With really good amenities, good natural toiletries, including facial toners, cleaning oils etc which adds to the boutique feel! The beds are very very comfortable, not the pillows are odd "they put wooden beads inside Japanese pillows and although they do provide 2 extra firm"ish" pillows, I was slightly disappointed as I'm allergic to feather so I had to stick to the beaded ones :/ do what I do, I always travel with a pillow packed in my luggage so I'm happy all the time. Breakfast is a bit odd but this is Japan and you gotta try the way they eat! And I have to admit, it might look odd but it's actually super tasty! Staff are Japanese, so expect all the politeness, courtesy, and extraordinary welcome you get from these people!

The location is very near the subway as well as the airport bus terminal (Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu) which are only 5-minute walk to the hotel. Akasaka is a banking and finance area. No shopping nor department stores is there. The street is convenient for food and entertainment. Hotel is clean and comfortable. Staff is courteous.However, the breakfast venue is very clammed (less than 20 seats). It is a not a proper cafeteria.There is a free spa and sauna for men on 2/F which looks like operated by third party. For ladies, you are required to walk 3 minutes to next Centurion Hotel at the same street. But it is not good for a lady to walk alone in the street at night.

The hotel was the tallest hotel in the area. It offers free wifi and the rooms looked great, but a little small - we had a hard time fitting all our luggage inside the room as the place was cramped! There were 3 people inside the room and they gave us an extra bed for the third person, that's why the place got so cramped. The wifi was fast and the service was exceptional. I have a problem with the breakfast buffet however, the breakfast area was small so people had to wait for a while to get a seat and the choices for the breakfast buffet were so few that I had to eat the same thing for 4 days straight. On our last day, we had to leave by 5am so we requested if we could have our free breakfast packed for us but they were not able to do so, we had to leave the hotel without any breakfast. But our overall experience was great and I highly recommend this hotel to tourists or guests!

I cannot tell you how awesome this place is and clean. I love it. Everyone kinda keeps to their self and really is in the heart of everything. Cannot give enough stars!!!! The lady in front is lovely and everything is explanatory. Have fun...

The hotel was ok and serviceable. For a hotel in its class it is really good. The location is convenient, right in the heart of the Akasaka district. Lots of restaurants, bars near by and very close to public transportation that can whisk you away to any part of the city very quickly or to the train stations and airports. Good value if you are working or are going to spend no time in your room. Avoid the breakfast, better places (even open 24/7) down the block. Like many budget hotels in Tokyo, rooms are small and dark, mattresses are old and too soft, and bathrooms are tiny. I go to Japan a lot so this is not just the perspective of a first time gaijin. Staff is really good and helpful, rooms are immaculate and front desk is very helpful. Only negative is that the climate control in the rooms is a little quirky and hard to control- love some fresh air but my window would not open. Tough to get a room in Tokyo this time of year on short notice (spring break and cherry blossom season), but if forced to would stay here again. Hats off to the desk staff.

review_body: This is the most disappointed we've ever been, with any hotel that we landed purely from TripAdvisor reviews. People, there's something wrong here. There are too many positive reviews -- I'm serious. This is a hole in the wall, tiny place with horrible filthy purple carpet in the hallway and a tiny lobby packed with people's suitcases and even a couple of mistreated birds sitting there in a tiny cage. The word "dump" comes to mind. I've traveled for years to Japan, and am no stranger to the size difference of a room in Tokyo and a room in other countries. Tokyo hotel rooms are infamous for being small. But please, consider that these rooms are the smallest of the small. They literally have no place to keep our two medium suitcases. You have to move them out of the way every time you want to go into the bathroom. It's the single worst value hotel I've ever stayed in. For two nights stay, admittedly at high season, we paid over $900. This is complete nonsense. It's a Motel 6 that has figured out a way to game the TripAdvisor system somehow. Seriously, this is a terrible, terrible investment -- don't even consider it.We're looking forward to getting out of here and into a normal quality hotel in Kyoto. If you can avoid the "Grand" Centurion, I would urge you to do so.

We stayed in this hotel on our recent trip to Tokyo. It was very easy to get to. If you arrive into Tokyo JR station it's just a metro ride to Akasaka-mitsuke metro station.The hotel is in the middle of the busy akasaka area where there are loads of bars and restaurants.The hotel is fairly new and the rooms are fairly small, though well equipped. If you are into swinging cars around the room well it's not the room! Wifi is free, there's a safe, kettle, fridge, comfortable bed, plenty of pillows, 42" at end of bed, magic toilet and all the toiletries you could dream off. I liked the fact that the window opened as well. Breakfast was fine, with the usual Japanese cuisine plus fruit, cereal, bread rolls and hot sausage etc. There is a drinks machine in foyer where you can get hot drinks and soft drinks all day for free.There is also a (free) spa but I didn't make it into it. I hired a wifi hotspot from hotel for 500 yen per day. Staff are very helpful and can speak reasonable English.There is a huge Bic Camera store close to hotel where you can buy a nice bottle of wine for £6. Sometimes it's nice to kick off the shoes, lie down on the bed, watch some Sumo fighting on the TV and have a glass of wine.

We stayed for 6 nights at this hotel over NYE 2015/2016. Love the location of this hotel, it's literally 2 mins walk from Akasaka Mitsuke train station. Lots of restaurants & shops on the same street and also all the streets surrounding the area. The hotel room was a family room, we have 2 double bed + 2 bunk beds for my teenagers. It was very tight for the 4 of us, we had no space to put our suitcases so we had to stay very organised and stacked some suitcases above the wardrobe. Bathroom was tiny but best showers & bathtub, the Japanese are so good at building stuff like that. Very small space but super efficient. The lobby has a lounge area where we ate our breakfast every morning. We ate the same breakfast food for 1 whole week! Rice, miso soup, seaweed, boiled egg, braised potatoes & carrots, bread rolls w/ butter, poached salmon, chicken sausages. If you don't want to eat the same thing every morning, I suggest you buy some wonderful bakeries when you go shopping for the day, and keep bakeries for your next day breakfast. We bought some bakeries from Maison Kayser for next day breakfast and it was a great change for all of us. The staff spoke English but nothing too deep, just very simple basic questions they can handle. I will stay here again if I visit because the location is a winner for sure and it was the most reasonably price for the size of my family.

review_body: the hotel looks great in online photographs and is just the same when viewed in person. friendly lobby staff, a small but comfortable room (in our case), very close to all the subway connections you need, a quick walk to the wonderful hei shrine and the imperial palace, surrounded with food, drinks, business and calm streets to walk in. you can walk to many famous parts of tokyo from here, or of course take the train. the hotel offers a nice breakfast in the morning and definitely try the coffee, it is a great pick-me-up for a long day of tokyo walking. definitely highly suggest staying at this hotel.

Very neat hotel, great service and excellent facilities. Impressed with all the little extra details they go to, to make your stay more accommodating. will say well priced also. Close to shops bars and reaturants A+ guys

This hotel is in a super location, being 3 minutes walk from a subway station that has 5 lines, so you can get anywhere from here very easily. There are also mountains of restaurants in the area within 5 minutes walk. The rooms are really good too. We had 2 adults and 2 teenage boys in the same room, and had plenty of space for all of us. The only small downside was the continental breakfast. Very basic - pretty much some cereal and bread rolls, unless you eat japanese breakfast. Overall, very good place to stay.

We stayed here for 4 nights early in the year and found this hotel to be in a great location with some added bonuses. If you are in to swinging cats, this is not the place for you. Its not really different to most Tokyo hotels but there is only space to open one suitcase at a time and you have to climb over your partner to get out of bed. Space is also at a premium at breakfast but it never held us up. The up side is a sensational bath area[at least for males] with multiple soak pools, some with minerals. and an adjoining sauna. The hotel itself is somewhat boutique like and is well cleaned and the beds were comfortable. The nearest subway is a short 3 minute walk away and it links to most of the tourist areas of Tokyo along with Tokyo station, making it an ideal location. The surrounding streets are filled with great dining and bar options.

We arrived in flurry of crazy family stress with about 10 bags (including snowboard gear) and the hotel staff couldn't have been more accommodating and helpful! The service remained exceptional throughout our stay.Our room was on the small size but nothing less than Tokyo standard and would have been totally fine without all our luggage taking up space. The furnishings were clean, modern and lovely and all beds (King bed and an extra single) were all comfortable. Both windows opened a bit too which is great if the room gets too warm.The breakfast was in a cosy dining area and totally fine - nothing crazy good but enough to fill us for the morning.There is a spa for males only in the hotel. Females have free access to a spa too but you have to exit the premises and I couldn't be bothered so not sure what it was like.The location is also great. The hotel is in the part of Akasaka that has a bevvy of great eateries and shops on narrow paved streets. You have an option of 2 train stations with one that is only a few short stops from Tokyo station. Perfecto!All in all, great value for such a great location and exceptional service. Oh, and free WiFi!!

The staff was friendly and very accommodating. The location was near a station and some shopping stalls, some street food stalls and convenience stores. The place was clean and the facilities were basic but complete. I must say though that the rooms were small. I'm a small girl but had to squeeze in some areas of the bedroom while walking around/

New and modern hotel. All services and in room facilities. The 24h hours men only spa is perfect just before go to sleep. Rooms are daily cleaned even if you leave them lately. Location is full of restaurant and shops. There are 2 metro station so is so well connected and taxi are around 24h. I will come back!

I must have researched hotels for 6 months and finally landed on this. The deciding factor for me was wanting an area where I felt my teenagers could tour independently and feel safe. I had originally wanted to stay in Shinjuku. I am so glad I changed my mind. The location of the hotel was perfect. 2 minutes for Akasaka Mitsuke Metro station which got us everywhere. Can't rave enough about the location. Plenty of restaurants for us to choose and very affordable.As we are a family of 5 we had two rooms so space wasn't too bad. We stayed in a superior double which has a couch which lies flat for the second bed. The toiletries and shower were terrific and there was complimentary bottles of water each day.The negative would be the breakfast but I knew that booking it so told myself that anything we ate was a bonus :) The reality is, it wasn't terrible. Two cereals, juice, coffee, rice, miso, some vegetables, salad each morning. On the weekend there was fresh fruit and canned fruit salad the rest of the week. The very best part was the pocket wi-fi. 500 Yen per day from the hotel. Absolutely amazing. Just don't let your teens use all the data. With that and a couple of aps I mastered the metro in like 1 day.It is not 5 star but I most certainly would stay again. Staff were lovely

I booked a double bed room with my mother and there was barely enough space to move around, let alone open our luggage. It looked much bigger in the photo and the view wasn't great either. All I see is a building of parking lots. The room, however, was new and clean. The staff was nice, helpful and speak English well.

The hotel is located at Akasakamitsuke Station, a big subway station which connect to many main subway line. Easy assess to almost everywhere in Tokyo. Getting from the airport via Airport link could be a bit difficult since you have to take those luggages down the subway.

Stayed at the Centurion Hotel Grand recently on a business trip to Tokyo.I was pleased to find that the room was larger than that of the APA Hotel that I stayed at previously.The hotel and my room were all very clean and up to date, well laid out and quiet.I found that the staff to be exceptionally helpful and professional.Need a massage? Try the Olive Spa as they do a great job and the prices for guests is lower than the posted price.Good location being within a 5 min walk of the Akasaka Mitsuke train station and the hotel is located on a street with plenty of places to eat or drink until late in the evening.Overall I am highly pleased with this hotel and have plans to stay here again for future visits.

There are some positive aspect and some other not so positive: rooms are ok, clean and silent. Breakfast is not good, and the common spaces like the lobby should be kept in a more appropriate way: no birds, no fishes... Well located and staff is very friendly! Rate is correct.

I'm giving this five stars even though I do have a few sizeable gripes. The reason I'm still going five stars though ;- Good value for money, breakfast included too - Rooms are small, but modern, well equipped, clean and quiet. Excellent bed. - - Super smart integrated phone chargers- Nice bathroom - Awesome location For the gripes, which have been mentioned by other people a lot too ;- Breakfast area is tiny, you can't always get a seat when going down to eat - Staff has major issues with English, which causes confusion Would absolutely go here again. If above two issues are fixed this would be a pretty legendary hotel!

The hotel is near Akasaka-mitsuke metro station which can be reached with a two-minute walk. The quartier is a lively one, full of restaurants and bars (and nothing else interesting for a tourist). The hotel is pleasant, with a friendly staff and offers everything you can expect. A public bath and sauna for men is at the second floor and is free for guests. Female guests can use another spa which is a short walk from the hotel. If you don’t want to exit the hotel you can have a drink in its very small bar (used also as breakfast room). Coffee and soft drinks are at guests’ disposal and we had no problem with wifi which worked perfectly. The room was pleasant, new and clean with tea and coffee facilities and free mineral water in the fridge. Unfortunately it had very limited space. Two people have difficulties to move around even if they travel with only two bags. But this seems to be common to Japanese hotel rooms.The breakfast is buffet style but can disappoint guests who judge according to the western standards. It is a very small buffet with basic breakfast (rice, soup, sausages, fish, jam, toast, coffee) in a very limited space. And this is the hotel’s major fault: the limited space of the breakfast room which is just a side of the lobby. Six-seven small tables which cannot accommodate many guests, it is highly likely you’ll not find a seat when the hotel is fully booked.

The hotel is well-located between 2 Metro stations which makes it easy to access the rest of Tokyo. There are plenty of restaurants, bars and convenience stores right outside the hotel. I couldn't have asked for better in terms of the hotel's location.The room was small but I guess it being Tokyo, that is to be expected. Nonetheless, it was very cosy. I have to compliment the hotel for being generous and thoughtful towards their guests. They provide the necessary toiletries as well as electrical points - there was no need to fight over the use of electrical points to charge our devices. Breakfast was simple. On the overall, the staff did their best in providing good service to us and we were very satisfied. This is a hotel I will certainly consider returning to when I visit Tokyo again.

I have been there for 5 nights during for a business trip. The hotel located in the heart of Asakasa, sounded by restaurants and bars. Its 2 minutes walk from one subway station and 5 minutes from another line. Very convenient. I have booked the double bed room which was tiny, as in many Tokyo hotels , but this is very tiny, I don't know how 2 people can be here together....still the room is occupied with all you need, big TV screen, small fridge, and of course very clean. The breakfast area is small, only few tables with very limited choice, but ok for start the day. The front desk people are helpful but some of them speak barely English, which is annoying.Bottom line, the location is great, all kind of restaurants just by the hotel, the airport shuttle arrives nearby to the Excl Hotel which is 3-4 minutes walk. Very convenient.Taxi from Shibuya station or Tokyo station to the hotel cost about 2200 Yen.

This is a nicely situated hotel in the Akasaka area of Tokyo. Rooms are small for US standards, but very comfortable!! The morning breakfast was also nice. I'd recommend this hotel given its comfort and also it's great location to shops, restaurants and metro stop.

I am staying here currently for past 5 days, and 2 more to go. While considering the hotel for a solo business visit, this is a great place to be. Centurion offers, multiple types of guests rooms. All are compact, very hygienic, and we'll maintained. The staff here speaks good English and Japanese. Being in heart of Tokyo at Akasaka, it's a minute literally from the nearest Mironuchi metro line and 3 minutes walking to Akasaka chiyoda line. Over hundreds of options to choose from for places to eat around here. Breakfast is satisfactory with English bread, butter, jam, cornflakes, and Japanese rice soup and salads. You also have options of some sausages and egg. Coffee and drinks are free throughout the day at the restaurant area. You can also buy some souvenirs inside. Laundry can be either self managed or can be done on call. Bathroom is a all Toto brand finish. With options of heating toilet seats as it gets here. Overall its a pleasant stay for someone looking to be near to everything in Japan's most busy centre. Nightlife is great around and Roppongi is just 15 minutes of walk.

I don't smoke but ended up in a smoking room. The staff, while not very proficient in english, were friendly enough to ensure most of the smoke smell was gone. The room barely had any smoke smell at all and was quite inhabitable after that. The room was very tiny though, and was literally just a bed, a desk, and a TV mounted on the wall. While small, the room had everything you would need - from toothbrush to a yukata. Morning breakfast buffet was a bit sad. The space for the breakfast is very small, and the food mediocre at best. The location for this hotel is great and close to plenty of restaurants. Given the price for this hotel, I would stay at it again.

The property is nestled in the bustling bar and restaurant area of Akasaka, also filled with love hotels, saunas and high-end options; however, its public bath and sauna facility are first rate and clean, it has a complimentary breakfast - not special but not to be found at a love hotel - and you are three minutes from multiple stations. A little pricy which keeps this from a 4-star rating but I saw families, so it's not an adults only option. It basically is a fine hotel after a late night when a warm bath and sweat are great for decompression.

The bad1) Room is tiny. For a bit tall guy, you have no room around your bed. And that's how big the room is, the size of your bed.2) There is really no restaurant. But as soon as you step out of the hotel, there are crazy lots of Japanese and other restaurants near the Akasaka station. Wont suffer for lack of options.3) The hotel has a 24 hour free porn channel. May not be very family and kid friendly4) The breakfast area is super small and options are limited.The good1) The service is usually friendly and fast2) Great location, very accessible and in the heart of Akasaka3) You can rent a mobile wi-fi from the counter for 500 Yen, which is great if you are travelling and badly need to be connected - for mail, maps, etc.4) Clean rooms & toiletsOverall, certainly not my first choice to stay in the Akasaka area, which I frequent. But if I don't have 2-3 of my favorite hotels available, I would rather stay here than somewhere far away from Akasaka.

This hotel is in a great location in Akasaka great choice of restaurants local to the subway. The room was clean tidy and modern the staff were very pleasant. The breakfast was ok like some else said the area was very small so get down early, but I did find out that you could have taken it to your room. Overall had a great stay.

We went for this hotel since in August the options are very limited specially if you don't book ahead. The hotel room was small but modern, the a/c worked well and the shower was great. The location is great and near the subway. The complimentary breakfast was nice but the eating area was very very tiny so better go there early on. Staff was super friendly. A bit overpriced but then again we all know Japan is expensive

This is very pleasant hotel in a good location for visiting Tokyo. We travelled as a family, and although the room was small we had 4 beds. There were yukatas and slippers, with a japanese styel bathroom. Breakfast is free, with a Japanese and western buffet. The food is good although the breakfast area is small. In the day there are free drinks in the lobby, and in the evening popcorn, candy floss and shaved ice. The desk staff are helpful. Overall, this is a good stay for a a family group.

Check-in - had some problems because the name given by the agency who booked us was spelled wrong, so I just said that yes, that was my reservation. They checked us in quickly after that. The room was ready upon our arrival.We got a triple room, which was pretty cramped, but it was beautiful nonetheless. The beds were so comfy and there were yukatas that we could use as pajamas (we wanted to take one home. If only we could!). The bathroom was also very nice and clean, it had complete amenities! They even have scrunchies for tying hair! The temperature for the shower was a little hard to control though. But nonetheless, I loved our room!The room got a bit cold at times, but it was easy to control the temperature. Room also came with a cable where you can just plug in your phone (any phone, I think). Sockets are pretty random, you can find one beside the bed, another on the foot of the sofa bed, another on the corner near the TV, and the last one on the other side of the sofa bed. TV had Japanese channels!There's laundry, microwave, sauna, in one of the floors, but I wasn't able to check it out anymore. Wish I did!Breakfast was the same everyday, which could get annoying if you're staying for a long time. They had rice, miso soup, sausage, cereals, nori, fruits, and four kinds of drinks.Location: Very great! Near the subway station, with convenience stores nearby! Lots of vending machines around, and there's a post box just around the block.Staff was very helpful too.Free wifi is a big plus, but it's kind of slow at times and I get disconnected--I don't know why...
